sen.j: 祇園甲部（ぎおんこうぶ、京都市東山区）は、京都で最大の京の花街。
sen.e: Gion Kobu in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City is the largest hanamachi ('flower town,' or geisha district) in Kyoto.
Gion Kobu in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City is the largest hanamachi ('flower town,' or geisha district) in Kyoto.
Gion Kobu in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City is the largest hanamachi ('flower town,' or geisha district) in Kyoto.

sen.j: 日本国内のみならず海外でも知られている。
sen.e: It is known abroad as well as in Japan.
It is known abroad as well as in Japan.
It is known abroad as well as in Japan.

sen.j: 江戸初期に八坂神社の門前で営業された水茶屋がこの花街の始まりである。
sen.e: Gion Kobu started with the opening of a teahouse in front of the gate of the Yasaka-jinja Shrine at the beginning of the Edo period.
Gion Kobu started with the opening of a teahouse in front of the gate of the Yasaka-jinja Shrine at the beginning of the Edo period.
Gion Kobu started with the opening of a teahouse in front of the gate of the Yasaka-jinja Shrine at the beginning of the Edo period.

sen.j: 後に行政からも花街として公認されることになったが、この際に団子をモチーフにした紋章が作られた。
sen.e: Subsequently, it received official approval for the hanamachi, and the emblem featuring dumpling cake was created.
Subsequently, it received official approval for the hanamachi, and the emblem featuring a dumpling cake was created.
Subsequently, it received official approval for the hanamachi, and the emblem featuring a dumpling cake was created.

sen.j: この紋章は現在も祇園甲部と祇園東の紋章として使われている。
sen.e: It is still used as the emblem for Gion Kobu and Gion Higashi.
It is still used as the emblem for Gion Kobu and Gion Higashi.
It is still used as the emblem for Gion Kobu and Gion Higashi.

sen.j: 江戸末期にはお茶屋が500軒、芸妓、舞妓、遊女合わせて1000人以上いたという。
sen.e: At the end of the Edo period, Gion Kobu was said to have boasted five hundred teahouses and more than one thousand of geisha, apprentice geisha and shogi (prostitutes) in total.
At the end of the Edo period, Gion Kobu was said to have boasted five hundred teahouses and more than one thousand geisha, apprentice geisha and shogi (prostitutes) in total.
At the end of the Edo period, Gion Kobu was said to have boasted five hundred teahouses and more than one thousand geisha, apprentice geisha and shogi (prostitutes) in total.

sen.j: 1872年、東京奠都によって繁栄に陰りが差した京都を立て直す為、槇村正直が博覧会の余興として都をどりを考案するが（詳細は「都をどり」の項を参照のこと）、この振り付けを担当したのが三世井上八千代である。
sen.e: To revitalize Kyoto, which was on the brink of decline due to the Tokyo-tento (designation of Tokyo as capital), Masanao MAKIMURA thought of showing the Miyako Odori (Dance of the Capital) in the Kyoto Exhibition as an entertainment, and Yachiyo INOUE III choreographed the dance (see 'Miyako Odori' for details).

To revitalize Kyoto, which was on the brink of decline due to the Tokyo-tento (designation of Tokyo as capital), Masanao MAKIMURA thought of showing the Miyako Odori (Dance of the Capital) in the Kyoto Exhibition as entertainment, and Yachiyo INOUE III choreographed the dance (see 'Miyako Odori' for details).

To revitalize Kyoto, which was on the brink of decline due to the Tokyo-tento (designation of Tokyo as capital), Masanao MAKIMURA thought of showing the Miyako Odori (Dance of the Capital) in the Kyoto Exhibition as entertainment in 1872, and Yachiyo INOUE III choreographed the dance (see 'Miyako Odori' for details).

sen.j: この時、以降の祇園甲部の舞いは井上流に限るとする取り決めが為され、現在まで祇園の舞は井上流一筋となっている。
sen.e: It was agreed upon at that time that the 'Gion Kobu no Mai' (Gion Kobu's dance) would be choreographed only by the Inoue School of Dance and it has still remained this way.
It was agreed at that time that the 'Gion Kobu no Mai' (Gion Kobu's dance) would be choreographed only by the Inoue School of Dance and it has still remained this way.
It was agreed at that time that the 'Gion Kobu no Mai' (Gion Kobu's dance) would be choreographed only by the Inoue School of Dance and it has still remained this way.

sen.j: この時期、祇園は文人や政治家等に愛され大いに繁栄した。
sen.e: During this period, Gion has been loved by many prominent figures such as literati and politicians, and has greatly prospered.
During this period, Gion has been loved by many prominent figures such as literati and politicians, and has greatly prospered.
During this period, Gion was loved by many prominent figures such as literati and politicians, and greatly prospered.

sen.j: 当時、『膳所裏』と呼ばれていた一部の地域は祇園乙部、後の祇園東（乙部の詳細は「祇園東」の項を参照のこと）として分離し、現代に至る。
sen.e: A portion of the area called "Zezeura" in Gion Kobu was separated to become Gion Otsubu, and Gion Otsubu became the present-day Gion Higashi (see 'Gion Higashii' for details on Otsubu).
sen.cmt: 膳所裏→[正しい読み方が不明です]
sen.e: A portion of the area called "Zezeura" in Gion Kobu was separated to become Gion Otsubu, and Gion Otsubu became the present-day Gion Higashi (see 'Gion Higashii' for details on Otsubu).
A portion of the area called "Zezeura" in Gion Kobu was separated to become Gion Otsubu, and Gion Otsubu became the present-day Gion Higashi (see 'Gion Higashi' for details on Otsubu).
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦が始まると白川沿いの北側は建物疎開で破壊された（その中に磯田多佳が経営していた『大友』（だいとも）が含まれていた）。
sen.e: When World War II started, the riverside to the north of the Shirakawa River was destroyed during building evacuation; among the destroyed buildings was the teahouse called "Daitomo," run by Taka ISODA.

When World War II started, the riverside to the north of the Shirakawa River was destroyed during building evacuation; among the destroyed buildings was the teahouse called "Daitomo," run by Taka ISODA.

When World War II started, the riverside to the north of the Shira-kawa River was destroyed during building evacuation; among the destroyed buildings was the teahouse called "Daitomo," run by Taka ISODA.

sen.j: この地域は現在は遊歩道となっている。
sen.e: The area has become a promenade.
Today, the area has become a promenade.
Today, the area has become a promenade.

sen.j: 終戦後（1945年-）、祇園甲部はすぐに営業を再開、その5年後に『都をどり』が南座で再開（後に本拠地である歌舞練場に戻り、今に至る）。
sen.e: Gion Kobu reopened right after the end of the war (1945), and five years later, the Miyako Odori was performed again at the Minamiza Theater (later and currently at the home base 'Kaburen-jo Theater').

Gion Kobu reopened right after the end of the war (1945), and five years later, the Miyako Odori was performed again at the Minamiza Theater (later and currently at the home base 'Kaburen-jo Theater').

Gion Kobu reopened right after the end of the war (1945), and five years later, the Miyako Odori was performed again at the Minamiza Theater (later and currently at the home base 'Kaburen-jo Theater').

sen.j: 昭和30年代から40年代にかけてお茶屋150軒、芸妓、舞妓合わせて600人を数えたが、時代の流れと共に花街の規模は縮小していった。
sen.e: From the late 1950's to the early 1960's, Gion Kobu boasted 150 teahouses and more than 600 of geisha and apprentice geisha in total, and yet Gion Kobu has reduced the scale of the hanamachi as time has gone by.

From the late 1950's to the early 1960's, Gion Kobu boasted 150 teahouses and more than 600 geisha and apprentice geisha in total. Yet Gion Kobu has reduced the scale of the hanamachi as time has gone by.

From the late 1950's to the early 1960's, Gion Kobu boasted 150 teahouses and more than 600 geisha and apprentice geisha in total; yet Gion Kobu has reduced the scale of the hanamachi as time has gone by.

sen.j: 古い街並みはビルに変わり、加えてバーやスナック、性風俗店の進出により環境が悪化する。
sen.e: Old streets have been replaced by new buildings, and as a result, the social environment has deteriorated, with the increasing number of bars, hostess bars, and adult entertainment business.
Old streets have been replaced by new buildings, and as a result, the social environment has deteriorated, due to the increasing number of bars, hostess bars, and adult entertainment business.
Old streets have been replaced by new buildings, and as a result, the social environment has deteriorated, due to the increasing number of bars, hostess bars, and adult entertainment business.

sen.j: 新橋地区（元吉町）の住民はこの乱開発に危惧を抱き、この地域の町並み保存を行政に働きかけた。
sen.e: Being concerned about rampant development, residents in the Shinbashi area (Motoyoshi-cho) pressed the government to preserve the old townscape of the area.
Being concerned about rampant development, residents in the Shinbashi area (Motoyoshi-cho) pressed the government to preserve the old townscape of the area.
Being concerned about rampant development, residents in the Shinbashi area (Motoyoshi-cho) pressed the government to preserve the old townscape of the area.

sen.j: この結果、新橋地区は修景地区に指定され、後に重要伝統的建造物群保存地区に選定される。
sen.e: Consequently, the Shinbashi area was designated as the Special Preservation and Improvement District, and later selected as the Important Preservation Districts for Groups of Historic Buildings.
Consequently, the Shinbashi area was designated as a Special Preservation and Improvement District, and later selected as an Important Preservation District for Groups of Historic Buildings.
Consequently, the Shinbashi area was designated as a Special Preservation and Improvement District, and later selected as an Important Preservation District for Groups of Historic Buildings.

sen.j: 一方、祇園町南側（とくに花見小路通周辺）は女紅場学園所有であるために乱開発は逃れ、歴史的風景特別修景地区に指定された。
sen.e: On the other hand, the south area of Gion around the Hanamikoji-dori Street in particular was spared from rampant development because the area was owned by Nyokoba-gakuen School, and it was designated as the Historical Landscape Preservation and Improvement District.
sen.cmt: 「歴史的風景特別修景地区」は「歴史的景観保全修景地区」のようです（参照：http://www.city.kyoto.lg.jp/tokei/page/0000057090.html）
sen.e: On the other hand, the south area of Gion around the Hanamikoji-dori Street was spared from rampant development because the area was owned by Nyokoba-gakuen School, and was designated as a Historical Landscape Preservation and Improvement District.

On the other hand, the south area of Gion around the Hanamikoji-dori Street was spared from rampant development because the area was owned by Nyokoba-gakuen School, and was designated as a Historical Landscape Preservation and Improvement District.

sen.j: この町のシンボルというべき舞妓も一時は20人以下へと落ち込んでいたが、近年徐々に回復し、現在は30人弱にまで増えていると言われる。
sen.e: The number of apprentice geisha, who are the poster child of the hanamachi, decreased to less than twenty at one point, but recently. the number has been gradually increasing and there are said to be a little less than thirty apprentice geisha today.

The number of apprentice geisha, who are the poster children of the hanamachi, decreased to less than twenty at one point, but recently. the number has been gradually increasing and there are said to be a little less than thirty apprentice geisha today.

The number of apprentice geisha, who are the poster children of the hanamachi, decreased to less than twenty at one point, but recently. the number has been gradually increasing and there are said to be a little less than thirty apprentice geisha today.

sen.j: 祇園は数多くの人物で彩られ、また名妓を輩出してきた。
sen.e: Gion has been filled with a variety of figures and produced renowned geisha.
Gion has been filled with a variety of figures and produced renowned geisha.
Gion has been filled with a variety of figures and produced renowned geisha.

sen.j: 江戸初期には大石内蔵助が一力茶屋で遊んでいた話は歌舞伎などでも知られ、江戸末期には後の新政府を樹立する多くの志士らによって利用され続けた。
sen.e: Even in a kabuki play, Kuranosuke OISHI is shown to have played around in the Ichiriki-jaya teahouse at the beginning of the Edo period, and many anti-shogunate samurai who were to establish the new government frequented the hanamachi.

Even in a particular kabuki play, Kuranosuke OISHI is shown to have played around in the Ichiriki-jaya teahouse at the beginning of the Edo period, and many anti-shogunate samurai who were to establish the new government frequented the hanamachi.

Even in a particular kabuki play, Kuranosuke OISHI is shown to have played around in the Ichiriki-jaya teahouse at the beginning of the Edo period, and many anti-shogunate samurai who were to establish the new government frequented the hanamachi.

sen.j: 当時、大和大路通に営業していた『魚品』の芸妓、中西君尾は志士らを新選組の目から逃れさせたことで有名。
sen.e: Kimio NAKANISHI, a geisha in the teahouse "Uoshina" on the Yamato-oji-dori Street, is known to have kept anti-shogunate samurai from being caught by the Shinsengumi.
Kimio NAKANISHI, a geisha in the teahouse "Uoshina" on the Yamato-oji-dori Street, is known to have kept anti-shogunate samurai from being caught by the Shinsengumi.
Kimio NAKANISHI, a geisha in the teahouse "Uoshina" on the Yamato-oji-dori Street, is known to have kept anti-shogunate samurai from being caught by the Shinsengumi.

sen.j: 時は下り、明治期に『加藤楼』のお雪（雪香）はアメリカの財閥であるモルガンと結婚して、後に『モルガンお雪』と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Moving to more recent times, Oyuki (Sekka), a geisha in the teahouse "Kato-ro (加藤楼)," married George D. Morgan of the Morgan family, who owned a large conglomerate, and she was called "Morgan Oyuki" afterwards.
sen.cmt: 加藤楼→Kato-ro[正しい読み方が不明です]雪香→Yukika[正しい読み方が不明です]
sen.e: Moving to more recent times, Oyuki (Sekka), a geisha in the teahouse "Kato-ro (加藤楼)," married George D. Morgan of the Morgan family, who owned a large conglomerate, and was called "Morgan Oyuki" afterwards.

Moving to more recent times, Oyuki (Sekka), a geisha in the teahouse "Kato-ro (加藤楼)," married George D. MORGAN of the Morgan family, who owned a large conglomerate, and was called "Morgan Oyuki" afterwards.
sen.cmt: 名字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 吉井勇の『かにかくに』の歌で有名なお茶屋『大友』の女将で芸妓である磯田多佳や、井上流の名手として、また後輩の育成に努めた松本佐多、ほかに早崎春勇、三宅小まめ、玉木里春、藤本竹葉、安藤孝子（現役当時の芸名は孝千代、後に11PMに出演）、岩崎究香、高田真知子、佳つ乃など京都のみならず、世間に花を添えてきた芸妓が数多くいる。
sen.e: Other geisha include: Taka ISODA who was a geisha and the proprietress of the teahouse "Daitomo," known by the tanka poem "Kanikakuya" (meaning somehow) by Isamu YOSHII; Sata MATSUMOTO who was an excellent performer of the Inoue School of Dance and engaged in nurturing junior geisha and apprentice geisha; and many more geisha such as Haruyu HAYASAKI, Komame MIYAKE, Satoharu TAMAKI, Takeha FUJIMOTO, Takako ANDO (whose geisha name was Takachiyo when active and appeared on a TV program called "11 PM"), Mineko IWASAKI, Machiko TAKADA (高田真知子), and Katsuno, all of whom have enlivened not only Kyoto but also the world outside Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 岩崎究香→Mineko IWASAKI[正しい読み方が不明です]高田真知子→Machiko TAKADA[正しい読み方が不明です]
sen.e: Other geisha include: Taka ISODA who was a geisha and the proprietress of the teahouse "Daitomo," known by the tanka poem "Kanikakuya" (meaning somehow) by Isamu YOSHII; Sata MATSUMOTO who was an excellent performer of the Inoue School of Dance and engaged in nurturing junior geisha and apprentice geisha; and many more geisha such as Haruyu HAYASAKI, Komame MIYAKE, Satoharu TAMAKI, Takeha FUJIMOTO, Takako ANDO (whose geisha name was Takachiyo when active and appeared on a TV program called "11 PM"), Mineko IWASAKI, Machiko TAKADA (高田真知子), and Katsuno, all of whom have enlivened not only Kyoto but also the world outside Kyoto.

Other geisha include: Taka ISODA who was a geisha and the proprietress of the teahouse "Daitomo," known by the tanka poem "Kanikakuya" (meaning somehow) by Isamu YOSHII; Sata MATSUMOTO who was an excellent performer of the Inoue School of Dance and engaged in nurturing junior geisha and apprentice geisha; and many more geisha such as Haruyu HAYASAKI, Komame MIYAKE, Satoharu TAMAKI, Takeha FUJIMOTO, Takako ANDO (whose geisha name was Takachiyo when active and appeared on a TV program called "11 PM"), Mineko IWASAKI, Machiko TAKADA (高田真知子), and Katsuno, all of whom have enlivened not only Kyoto but also the world outside Kyoto.

sen.j: 最近では芸妓としては初のジャズシンガーの真箏がいる。
sen.e: Lately, there is a geisha called Makoto who became the first Jazz singer among geisha.
Recently, there is a geisha called Makoto who became the first Jazz singer among geisha.
Recently, there is a geisha called Makoto who became the first Jazz singer among geisha.

sen.j: 現在、祇園甲部芸妓組合の会長に就任しているのは芸妓で井上流名取である小富美で、ほかにまめ晃、斗美千代、豆爾、まめ鶴、小萬、小鈴、豆弘、豆花、山口小喜美、照古満、寿々葉など代表的な芸妓らがいる。
sen.e: The current chairperson of the Gion Kobu Geisha Association is Kofumi, who has received a name from the Inoue School of Dance, and there are other known geisha such as Mameko, Tomichiyo, Mameni, Mametsuru, Koman, Kosuzu, Mamehiro, Mamehana, Mameka, Kokimi YAMAGUCHI, Terukoma and Suzuha.
sen.cmt: まめ晃→[正しい読み方が不明です]斗美千代→Tomichiyo[正しい読み方が不明です]豆花→Mamehana[正しい読み方が不明です]
sen.e: The current chairperson of the Gion Kobu Geisha Association is Kofumi, who received a name from the Inoue School of Dance. Other known geisha include Mameko, Tomichiyo, Mameni, Mametsuru, Koman, Kosuzu, Mamehiro, Mamehana, Mameka, Kokimi YAMAGUCHI, Terukoma and Suzuha.

The current chairperson of the Gion Kobu Geisha Association is Kofumi, who received a name from the Inoue School of Dance; other known geisha include Mameko, Tomichiyo, Mameni, Mametsuru, Koman, Kosuzu, Mamehiro, Mamehana, Mameka, Kokimi YAMAGUCHI, Terukoma and Suzuha.

sen.e: Onshu-kai (dance performance) from October 1 to 7

sen.j: 事始め
sen.e: Kotohajime (an event in which geisha visit their teachers and teahouses to thank them for their support in the year and for continued support in the new year)

sen.j: おことうさん
sen.e: Okotosan (an event on the last day of the year in which geisha visit teahouses to say in the Kyoto dialect 'Okotosan,' or roughly meaning 'it's been busy')
